dialogues.text: Joe's eyes fill with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears fill her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks her in the eye. Shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did it for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know why you did it. (She looks at him) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a thousand things he could suddenly say. And sudd nothing, as he fights tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I could give it back to you. If I could give you back who you were-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is who I am. Right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They clasp each other and hug, and all the pain drains aw They kiss. As they break she looks into her husband's eye

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So are you ready to fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe looks at his wife. His eyes filled with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valerie getting ready. She puts on make-up. A grey suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many of you know who put the 16 words in the State of the Union address?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arguably the most important speech the president makes all year. Never more important when the nation is on the brink of war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe steps out onto a stage. Packed to the rafters. Kids s on window ledges, others hang over balconies. SILENCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many of you know who put it in? (No hands.) How many of you know my wife's name? (Everyone in the hall.) How do you know one and not the other?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE WILSON (cont'd) How did the question move from "Why are we going to war?" to "Who is that man's wife". I asked the first question. Someone else asked the second. It worked. Its still working. Because we still don't know the truth. But you all know my wife's name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valerie sits in the back of a cab, looking out of the win

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Public officials swear an oath to uphold the constitution. That is their duty. They must be kept to their oath. That is yours. This offense wasn't committed against me. Nor against my wife...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was committed against you. And if you ever feel angry. Misrepresented. Ashamed even.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do something about it. In 1787 as Benjamin Franklin left the Constitution Hall after the last drafting session, he was stopped by a woman on the street. She asked--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -what manner of government have you bequeathed us? Ben said 'A Republic madam. If you can keep it.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you can keep it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sa'ad and his family walk out of the jetway and are greet by officials and men in uniform. Sa'ad smiles and shakes hands. His wife nervously shepherds their children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The responsibilty for this country does not lie in the hands of a privileged few.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sa'ad, a Korean man and two officers of the Sepah revolutionary guard ride in a four wheel drive through ru Iranian countryside, reflected on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are strong and we are free from tyranny only for as long as each and every one of us remembers their duty as citizens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sa'ad arrives at the heavily fortified reactor. He is introduced to several men the last of which is Manucher V the arms dealer Valerie was tracking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to the revolution my brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sa'ad looks up at the state of the art facility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALERIE GETS OUT OF THE CAB. She walks down the street pa the gleaming government buildings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whether its a pothole at the end of your street or a lie in the State of the Union Address..Speak up. Ask the question. Demand the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valerie walks. We see the Capitol dome behind her. She be to climb steps..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Democracy is not a free ride...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man I'm here to tell you that. But its where we live. And if we do our job its where our children will live. God bless America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A roar erupts from the auditorium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valerie climbs the steps. Suddenly she is engulfed in flashes. Dozens of photographers. Reporters. She climbs t steps. She passes between the two enormous statues to the Spirit of Justice and The Majesty of the Law --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valerie walks onto the floor of the Oversight Committee. Cameras. Microphones. Press photographers. She sits befor microphone. Swallows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Chairman and members of the committee. My name is Valerie Plame Wilson, and I am honored to have been invited to testify under oath before the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform on the critical issue...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shot dissolves into the REAL VALERIE PLAME delivering testimony to the chamber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...of safeguarding classified information. I'm grateful for this opportunity to set the record straight. I served the United States loyally and to the best of my ability as a covert operations officer for the Central Intelligence Agency. I worked on behalf of the national security of our country, on behalf of the people of the United States until my name and true affiliation were exposed in the national media on July 14th, 2003, after a leak by administration officials. Today I can tell this committee even more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REAL VALERIE FOOTAGE (cont'd) In the run-up to the war with Iraq I worked in the Counter Proliferation Division of the CIA, still as a covert officer whose affiliation with the CIA was classified. I raced to discover solid intelligence for senior policy makers on Iraq 's presumed weapons of mass destruction program. While I helped to manage and run secret worldwide operations against this WMD target from CIA headquarters in Washington , I also traveled to foreign countries on secret missions to find vital intelligence. I loved my career because I love my country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On March 6th 2007 Scooter Libby was found guilty of perju obstruction of justice and making false statements to the FBI, concerning the leaking of Valerie Plame's identity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was handed the maximum sentence: two and a half years prison, and a $250,000 fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On July 2nd 2007. The President used his executive author to commute the court's sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Valerie left Washington and found a new home in S Fe. They live there today, with their children.
